Name: Rate It!
Description:
Do you have what it takes to know how others rate?

Rate It! is the greatest of all the get-to-know-you family party games and guarantees fun and exciting surprises with every turn of a card.  You'll be amazed at the things you will find out about your family and your friends!

Players have to rate different people, movies, sports team, etc...  Players also use the erasable paddle to predict how other players will rate it.  On the back of the paddle is an erasable tally.  First to ten wins.  To keep the game interesting...there are many ways to rate items:

Thumbs up/thumbs down
Making the grade
Overrated/underrated
Star Rating
Face Rating
All Play (1-10)

Name: Legend of the Five Rings: The Battle of Beiden Pass – Basic Training for the Armies of Rokugan
Description:
The Battle of Beiden Pass was the first 2-player starter set for the Legend of the Five Rings CCG.

The starter set allows the players to play out the Battle of Beiden Pass, in which the Crab Clan have abandoned their centuries-old post protecting the empire from the forces of the Shadowlands, creating an alliance with their enemy in an attempt to take Beiden Pass, the crossroads of the empire. Only the Dragon Clan, aided by the disgraced Lion Clan samurai, Toturi, and his army of ronin, can stop them.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
Setting: Legend of the Five Rings

Name: Yahtzee Bowling
Description:
Instead of dice, this game uses five bowling pins with the numbers 1 through 6 on its hexagon sides.  Two players or teams take turns rolling the ball at the pins.  As in standard Yahtzee, you can hold pins after your first roll to try to get the best combination possible in rolls two and three.  The highest combination between the players or teams wins.  No other score is kept.

This game was given as a Wendy's kids meal promotional item and is based on one of the games featured on Hub TV's "Family Game Night" game show.

Name: Tempo Tempo
Description:
In Tempo Tempo, the players have to match patterns to animals.

At the start of the game, each player receives a set of animal cards (cow, rabbit, dog, cheetah, hyena and ladybug). There is also a deck of pattern cards; each of these cards shows a pattern that appears on one of the animals.

The game is played in rounds. Each round, someone reveals a pattern card, then players must race to play the matching animal card. The first player to play an animal may keep the pattern card if he played the right animal; he then returns the animal card to his hand. If he played the wrong animal, both his animal card and the pattern card are discarded.

After all pattern cards have been revealed, the player who has collected the most pattern cards wins.

Name: "A Dog's Life"
Description:
Promotional game made by a top British dog-food supplier (still doing that in 2011.
A simple roll and move game. Each player chooses one of the dogs listed and places their playing counter there. Each player is given 20 biscuits (provided by Mum I guess) and any remaining biscuits are placed into the pool (a biscuit tin). So, if four are playing this, Mum has to provide at least 80 biscuits. They must have liked their biscuits back then.
If your piece lands on a picture square, you must obey the instruction. Most often it will ask you to give X biscuits or take X biscuits, from the pool or/and other players.
Once a dog reaches home square 90, that dog tales all the biscuits left in the pool. The player with the most biscuits, wins.

Name: TiddlyGolf
Description: A variant of Tiddlywinks (as are all of this publisher's game). You get a green plastic target in which you have to tiddle your wink. Each attempt counts as a stroke and the player with the lowest strokes after 18 holes, wins.

Name: Flirt
Description:
In Flirt, all the players flirt with each other, until they get married at the end of the game. Who loves whom? And how much?

During the game, each player flirts with all several other players. All the actions – such as flirting, sending text messages or giving your heart away – bring in flirting points. Who will flirt the best, gain the most flirting points and become the "best" couple?

At the beginning of the game, each player receives a character (or two characters in a three-player game), two hearts belonging to that character and two relationship tokens, and a pawn, which is placed on the board. Then, each player thinks up a term of endearment for himself. When players address each other, they should use this term of endearment. A player who fails to do so correctly loses a relationship point.

The game is played in turns. On his turn, a player rolls two dice, picks one, and move his pawn as many spaces as the die shows. (In a three-player game, the player rolls one die, and selects one of his pawns to move.) After moving the pawn, the player may flirt with one character of the opposite sex whose pawn is on the same space or an adjacent space. If he does so, this strengthens the relationship between the two characters. This is measured by placing flirting points on the "love barometer". If two characters have four flirting points, they fall in love. After four more points, they get engaged, and after another four points, they get married.

Furthermore, if the pawn has landed on a heart space, the player may either give one of his hearts to another player, or ask for a heart from another player (who then has to give one of his hearts to the asker).

If the pawn has landed on a text message space, the player draws one of the text message cards, reads it out loud and places it face-down in front of him. If no more cards remain in the draw pile, the player can either give one of his cards away or ask to receive a card from another player (who then has to give one of his cards to the asker).

The game ends when a pair of characters have married. Now, each player scores points as follows:

    For the highest relationship status achieved (with any one other character): 4 points for being in love, 8 points for being engaged and 12 points for having married.
    -1 point for each of your own hearts, +2 points for each heart from another player.
    -1 point for each negative text message, +2 points for each positive text message.
    +1 point for each remaining relationship token.


The player who has scored the most points wins.

Name: Umbra Turris
Description:
Umbra Turris is new skirmish level miniatures game in which players control 6-12 heroes who create a party, trying to gain fame and wealth in ruins of old, grim city of Umbra Turris.
Using high quality miniatures and free intuitive rules players can assemble and highly customize their own band of heroes and then lead them to death or glory in one of six scenarios provided with rules. Additional rules such as random magic items, quests and terrain rules ensure big variety of games. 
Game uses simple and effective mechanic which uses dice rolls, bidding and actions, with alternating activation.

Rules are available in English, Spanish, and Polish. You can download them for free on Spellcrow's blog about the Umbra Turris universe - http://utchronicles.com/utchronicles/?page_id=73

Name: Trains, Planes & Automobiles
Description:
Ride the rails? Fly the skies? Drive the highways and byways? In this fast-playing fun game for the whole family, up to six players are news reporters in the late 1950s racing across the country to beat other players to the cities with the scoops.

Each player in Trains, Planes, and Automobiles is given a secret assignment city, along with one group city that everyone knows. Each player then receives plane tickets, train tickets, and rental car miles to get to the cities; the trick is some cities can reached only with one or two tickets while some can be reached with all three. You can play Bad Weather cards on other players flying, or Auto Breakdowns on players driving, and Train Delays on rail riders.

Name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – Never Night  Asylum Pack
Description:
Description from the publisher:

The hunt for Ancient Relics takes the different factions of Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game to the glaciated shores and frozen mountains of Antarctica. Dedicated cartographers, gun-toting thugs, insidious cultists, and terrifying beasts seek to unlock the secrets frozen in time beneath the ice in Never Night, the fourth Asylum Pack in the "Ancient Relics" cycle.

The Silver Twilight undertakes its first expedition to Antarctica, hoping to unlock powers previously undreamt and unknown. Meanwhile, mad sailors, gibbering monsters, corrupted cultists, scarred hit men, and others all struggle to advance their own goals in the desolate climes of a land where all summer the sun glares down and it is "Never Night".

Never Night continues the Ancient Relics cycle's theme of exploring the increasing influence of the Ancient Ones in the world outside New England. Beneath the ice of Antarctica, great powers lie frozen, untouched and waiting for untold ages.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Call of Cthulhu – The Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – The Breathing Jungle  Asylum Pack
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

The Great Old Ones and those who would oppose them continue to hunt powerful relics in The Breathing Jungle. With this third Asylum Pack in the "Ancient Relics" cycle for Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game, players will discover the power of new items that disappear and resurface throughout human history. This expansion cycle is based on the theme of the global influence of the Ancient Ones and their cults and moves the action from H.P. Lovecraft's dread-filled New England to the wider world.

While the Great Ones strengthen their global reach, investigators, criminals, and cultists wield ancient artifacts and invoke powerful curses. This sixty-card Asylum Pack (three copies each of 20 cards) takes your game out of New England to the rainforests of Mesoamerica. Find hidden cultists and forbidden sacrifices as the story shifts to eons old locales in The Breathing Jungle.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Call of Cthulhu – The Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Battlestar Galactica: Official Variant Rules
Description:
This is a print-and-play expansion and is available online at the FFG website. (See Web Links section.)

It adds the following variants:

    No Sympathizer
    Two Player Game
    One Player Game
    Fully Cooperative Game


(Note that because these variants were developed before the printed expansions, they are not necessarily compatible.)

Name: Dreck am Stecken
Description:
Murder in the night club! Ede K., host of nightly poker games, lies dead in his office. Next to him is a mysterious list, which contains the names of six of the city's most notorious crooks. They are quickly tracked and arrested. But which of them is the murderer? And what crimes have the others committed?

In Dreck am Stecken, slip into the role of one of the crooks and find out what crimes the others have committed so that you may get a more lenient punishment!

Name: Nimble Spider
Description:
All cards are dealt evenly among players.
Each player plays one card at a time and if it matches with the card on the table he takes the trick.
The Object is to take as many spiders as possible.

Name: Wissens-Quiz Der Mensch
Description:
The players have to collect 8 knowledge chips of every color. The chips are rewarded for answering one of 1000 questions out of different fields of 'human' knowledge: 
body, viscera, sexual reproduction/sex education, nutrition/healthiness, cardiovascular system/bloodstream, nervs, mind, diseases/cure, human being (in general)

During player's turn die is rolled; he/she may move into any direction, but not vice versa; occupied spaces may be crossed.
Appropriate card is drawn, die is used to pick a question - if the answer is correct, player may add an additional turn - moving again. You pick a chip if you find a correct answer on a space of the outer circle.
To compensate lack of knowledge children may draw - if they fail - an additional card.
Content:
Board 30x 30 cm, 110 cards with more than 1000 questions
8 register cards (diff. colours), 6 meeples, 48 coloured chips, 1 die, rules

Name: Quick Picks Family Feud Game
Description:
From the publisher:

The Survey Says... Now even MORE fun for everyone! The Family Feud Quick Pick edition features 45 rounds of survey questions and answers to one of America's longest running and most beloved TV Game Shows. With everything from the Face Off to the Feud to the Fast Money Round, The Family Feud Quick Pick edition offers all the fun of the TV show in this convenient travel-friendly tin! So play, pass, and steal your way to victory. The top eight answers are on the board, do you know what the "SURVEY SAYS"?!! Contents: Scoreboard, Strike Indicator, 3 "X" Markers, Instruction/Survey Question Booklet, 1 Dry Erase Marker

Name: Welt des Automobils
Description:
What is the fastest series-produced car in the world? When was the first crash test dummy built? And what is the Michelin Man's real name? Welt des Automobils (World of Cars) is a quiz game with 600 questions about car models, car manufacturers, advertising slogans and technology.

In each round, one player reads the question on a card, followed by the five possible answers. Unlike most other trivia games, the number of correct answers to the question ranges from one to five, but players don't know how many answers are correct. After reading through the answers once, the player reads them again one by one. Players secretly decide whether they think an answer is correct, hiding one of their answer tokens in hand if they think it is. Players reveal their guesses simultaneously, then place their tokens on the numbered answer card.

After players have guessed on all five answers, the correct answers are revealed, and the players may move forward on the scoring track:

     If a player has placed one or more tokens on incorrect answers, he does not move on the scoring track.
     If a player has placed tokens only on correct answers, he moves forward a number of spaces equal to the number of (correct) answers he selected.


After an agreed-upon number of questions, the game ends, and the player who is furthest on the scoring track wins.

Name: Viajero Loco
Description:
En "Viajero Loco" tienes que completar tu viaje primero que los demás jugadores. El mapa representa la geografía colombiana y los modos de desplazarse por ella (Avión, Tren, Barco, Caballo) Cada carta representa una ciudad o un medio de transporte y tienes que conectarlas antes que alguien más lo haga. Quien primero se deshaga de todas sus cartas es el ganador entonces los demás jugadores revisan con cuantas cartas quedaron en su mano y ese será su puntaje negativo.
Rápido, fácil y educativo, el juego es apto tanto para niños como para adultos.

--

In "Crazy Traveler" you have to complete your journey before the other players complete theirs. The map represents the Colombian geography and the cards represents the cities and the transport type to travel between them (plane, train, boat or horse) the players must connect all their cards before anyone else does. The first player to get rid off all his cards is the winner then the other players show how many cards were in their hands and that is their negative score.

Fast, easy and educational, the game is suitable for both children and adults.

Name: Ein Mann. Ein Spiel.
Description:
A man must do what a man must do.

That's the guiding principle of Ein Mann. Ein Spiel. ("One man. One game."), designed by Marcel-André Casasola Merkle and based on the book "Ein Mann. Ein Buch." ("One man. One book.") It's not enough for a man to know a few things about life, but he must also act well. At times he decides to make a difference, sometimes he must be steadfast and other times he must escape.

Each man has important choices to make in his life: Will I father a child? Or would I prefer to become Pope? Perhaps both? Or would I rather give myself over to a life of crime? Am I tough, am I wise, or am I practical? Will I re-invent myself during this game? With strategic skill, the players attempt to master life, achieve goals and develop their personality. At the end of the game, they are scored.

Name: Pappsatt
Description:
Oh no! The zoo keeper is sick today! Who will feed the animals?
Good thing you’re here - grab a feeding bucket and let’s get cracking! 
But which animal gets which food? Does the penguin get a nut and the squirrel get a fish? And in where exactly does the lion live?

A combination of memory and roll-and-move game. The players take turns in clockwise order. The player in turn rolls the die, and moves forward or backward. If he lands on a bucket symbol, het gains more food (if he has free hands - the meeples can only hold two bucktes each). At an enclosure door, he opens it (reveals the hidden animal), and feeds it if he has the right food (for example, meat for lion and crocodile). A wild symbol allows to move to any free space.

Game proceeds until one player manages to feed five animals, and is declared winner.

The rules contains a variant for childrens of age 3, with open enclosure doors (removing the memory aspect).

Name: Yodd
Description:
Yodd is a drawless connection and territory game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the spaces (cells) of an initially empty hexagonal grid of hexagons (board). The suggested board size is between 6 and 10 cells per side. Both players must have access to a sufficient supply of black and white stones.

Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, pass or place one or two stones of any colors on empty cells. On their first turn, Black can only place one stone. At the end of your turn, there must be an odd number of groups on the board. A group is an entire set of interconnected stones of the same color. A single stone, not connected to others of its color, is also a group.

When both players pass in succession, the game ends, and the player with fewer groups on the board wins.

				
				
					NotesDouble placement serves as both a first-move equalizer and a way to make the game playable under the group restriction rule.

Apart from the intended goal of eliminating draws (they would be common otherwise), forcing an odd number of groups at the end of a turn has some tactical implications that lend the game a loose single-placement feel. For example, groups separated by two empty cells cannot be merged on a single turn, as the player would need another placement to restore the group count to an odd number. Also, the diamond connection (two stones at each end of a four-cell rhombus) is safe if the opponent has exactly zero or two groups adjacent to the intermediate cells, and unsafe otherwise.

Endgames are also quite tricky under this rule: you will often want to merge two of your own groups or create another enemy group, but you will be unable to do so because you can no longer restore the group count to an odd number.

Name: Open End
Description:
Open End is a communication game about newspaper headlines. At the start of each round, a partial headline is given, and each player guesses in which newspaper category the headline belongs: literature, feuilleton, media, business, travel, science, panorama, politics or sport? After a consensus has been reached, the first points are awarded.

The players then continue with each of them writing an ending for the partial headline. One of the players, the reader, collects the sentences and reads them all aloud. The players then vote for their favourite sentences, which awards points to the creators of those sentences. More points will go to the most compelling answer than to the correct answer!

Name: ZEFIX!-Memo
Description: ZEFIX!-Memo is similar to Memory in that the game is played with tiles, which come in pairs, and on a turn a player flips two tiles – keeping them if they match and returning them face-down if they don't. What's different is that the tile pairs don't have identical images, but rather one tile features a choice Bavarian insult and the other depicts this insult visually. When all the tiles have been collected, the game ends, and the player who made the most matches wins.

Name: Gemischtes Doppel 3
Description:
Gemischtes Doppel 3, the successor to Gemischtes Doppel and Gemischtes Doppel 2, is an unusual German memory-type game in which paired cards may look quite different as matching cards are connected through spoonerisms. Each card in a pair shows a word that is a similar-sounding anagram of the other card's word, with each word being accompanied by its own illustration.

The format originates in "the world's shortest column" (two words ... plus two pictures) from the weekly Süddeutsche Zeitung Magazin. The juxtaposition of incongruous concepts, the odd but perfectly understandable expressions for familiar concepts that often result on at least one side of the anagram, and the deadpan stock photography illustrations are all played for absurd humour.

This sort of memory based on playing with words is more difficult than the usual one. The funny images displaying these words add to the fun.

Name: 逃走中 THE ボードゲーム (Run for Money the Board Game)
Description:
In the popular Japanese TV show Run for Money Tousouchuu (é€ƒèµ°ä¸­) contestants take the roles of Runners as they try to avoid capture by the Hunters.  Confined to a predesignated area of play, the Runners earn more money for every second that they avoid the Hunters until the game time expires.  Should a Runner choose to surrender before time is up, they can use a pay phone to exit the game and they will receive money equal to the time until they quit.  However, if a Runner is tagged by a Hunter not only are they eliminated from the competition but they also receive ZERO cash.  To make matters more interesting, the Runners are given missions via their cell phones.  Successfully completing a mission may give the Runners more cash or it may prevent more Hunters from entering play.  From start to finish, Tousouchuu is a game of risk vs reward.

In Tousouchuu THE Board Game, 2-5 players assume the role of Runners as they try to earn the most money possible without being caught by a Hunter.  As Missions come up, the Runners have to decide whether or not they will risk participation or if they'd rather hide to avoid being discovered and eliminated.  But unlike the TV show, Missions have an added bonus: Runners who successfully complete a Mission earn powerful Items that will help them avoid capture by the Hunters.

As the time ticks away and the money adds up, the Hunters continue their patrol.  Once a Runner is spotted by a Hunter, the chase is on!  Escaping the inhumanly fast Hunters will require both luck and endurance.  Run out of either and you will be caught and sent off to Detention.  But even while eliminated, you may find that sometimes even the Hunters are in need of Informants...

At the end of the game, the winner is the Runner with the most earned cash. Will you last until the time line hits zero?  Will you Surrender and walk away with only a portion of the cash?  Or will you get caught by the Hunters and receive absolutely nothing?

Tousouchuu THE Board Game features a double-sided game board and time-line for either a Short Game (for beginners) or Exciting Game (for those wanting a challenge).

Name: Forty Two
Description:
FortyTwo is a quiz game. It is played with cards which shown three questions on the front (marked in blue, yellow or red) and a number of points on the back. A card with difficult questions will be worth more points. The questions require that the player lists several items, e.g. Name six animals that can strech out their tongue, or name seven Germanic tribes, or name ten words that end in -heit.

On a players turn, he chooses how many points he will attempt to win (and thus the difficulty of the question). He will then roll a die, which determines whether he should answer the blue, yellow or red question on the card. The colour also determines how much time the player gets to answer the question: 60 seconds for a blue question, 45 seconds for a yellow question and 30 seconds for a red question.

A player doesn't need to answer the question alone, though. He can offer other players points for their assistance. If a correct answer is given within the time, the player and his helpers score points. The first player to reach 42 points wins the game.

Name: Call My Bluff
Description:
A game of bluff and double bluff.
One player each round is the Bluffer who has to take a Bluff Card. He reads out one of the two words on the card and the three definitions for that word, and then chooses one of the definitions of his choice and the other players can bet on whether it is true or not. They have three possible bets (they must bet on the word, but you can bet 5, 10, 15, or 20).
After everyone has bet, the result is made known. If it is true, those who correctly predicted the result get points equal to their bet. The incorrect bets are totalled up and the points given to the Bluffer. The Bluffer role then passes to the left.
The first player to score 250 points is the winner
Contents
56 Betting Cards
672 Bluffs
1 Scorepad

Game is based on the BBC revival program in the 1980's and features various team captains who have taken part.

Name: Villains
Description:
You are the leader of a fiendish organization bent on dominating "The City", but you are are not alone in the quest to become its undisputed master. Your enemies are lurking in the shadows, watching your every move. If you desire any chance of completing your devilish plans then secrecy must be your watchword. Keep your enemies guessing with bluffs, misdirection, and cunning strategy.

Villains is a 3-5 player game where each player represents a different faction of archetypal villains (players can choose from the invading aliens, an organized crime family, the robot uprisings, invading soviets and more).

Each turn the players secretly set their evil plans in motion by placing face down action tokens in different areas of the city. These tokens allow players to deploy troops, play action cards, initiate battles and use special faction specific abilities.

There are two paths to victory in a game of Villains: be the first player to complete four of your faction's plans or alternatively be the first player to achieve ten victory points by controlling important locations in The City.

Name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Lions of the Rock
Description:
Description from the publisher:

From their seat of power at Casterly Rock, a seat nearly as powerful as the Iron Throne itself in wealth and influence, the rich and powerful lords of House Lannister are raising the banners of war. Beneath the golden lion on a crimson field as red as spilt blood ruthless lords, devious ladies, cunning knights, and vast armies are forming to proclaim to Westeros the words of House Lannister: "Hear Me Roar!"

Lions of the Rock is the sixth Deluxe Expansion for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game, featuring 165 cards new to the LCG card pool – three copies each of 55 unique cards – that add deck-building opportunities and strategic depth to your game.

The cards included in Lions of the Rock deepen the existing strengths of House Lannister, as well as adding some new avenues of strategy to explore. Forming the core of Lions of the Rock are the formidable members of the Lannister family: the ruthless patriarch Tywin, the treacherous queen Cersei, the Kingslayer Jaime, and the beguiling Tyrion. Each wields power as naturally as dragons breathe fire, backed by the limitless wealth of Casterly Rock and the unbreakable will of House Lannister's honor and willingness to repay any debt in blood. As anyone in Westeros will tell you – a Lannister always pays his debts...

In-game, each Lannister represents a different approach to victory, around which entire decks could be built, from Tyrion's synergy with the Clansman trait, to Tywin's breathtaking seizure of power based on having lots of gold in play during Dominance, to Cersei's ability to claim power whenever you win intrigue challenges (playing very well into the new The Power Behind the Throne agenda). Working separately, the Lannisters are merely powerful. Working together, the might of the Lannisters can become unstoppable.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: A Game of Thrones – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: Rival
Description:
RIVAL is a collection of 5 two player abstract games, all played on a board consisting of black hexagons divided into diamonds, white hexagons and white triangles and none of the individual games is called RIVAL. These games are:-
 STARTRAP
 The object is surround a white star with your own pieces whilst preventing your opponent doing likewise. Each player has 16 playing pegs which move "diagonally" on black diamonds, one guard peg which blocks a black diamond to all other pegs and one jumper peg which occupies a point where black hexagons meet and blocks all movement through that point.
 MASTERSPY
 A chess like game played on black diamonds in which each player starts with 10 hunters, 4 detectives, 2 secret agents and a masterspy and the object is to capture your opponents masterspy.
 TWENTYONE
 Each player starts with 7 pairs of counters numbered 1 to 7 which move on black diamonds only. The object is to surround a white star with counters that add up to 21 whilst preventing your opponent from doing likewise.
 FIFTEENS
 Each player starts with 15 counters numbered 0 to 9, one each of values 0, 1,8 and 9 and two each of the rest. The object is to make groups of 3 counters on a black hexagon (one on each diamond) which add up to 15. One of those three counters may be the opponents.
 BLOCKER
 Played on the white diamonds only, players start with 12 counters and 3 guards each. Players take turns in rolling a d6 which generates their movement allowance. Movement may be divided between more than one piece. To capture an opponents piece one must use the full movement allowance on a single piece and land on an opponent's piece thus eliminating it. The object is to eliminate all opponent's pieces.

Name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – The Grand Melee
Description:
Description from the publisher:

The Grand Melee is the second monthly Chapter Pack of the "A Tale of Champions" cycle of expansions for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game. It introduce sixty cards - three copies each of twenty never-before-seen characters, events, locations, and attachments to give you more A Game of Thrones specific multiplayer deck-building options than ever before.

This Chapter Pack delves deeper into the new keywords introduced in this cycle by introducing powerful characters with the Joust and Melee keywords like new versions of Robert Baratheon and Thoros of Myr. The Grand Melee also features more support for A Game of Thrones multiplayer game by way of cards that are designed to grow in strength when played against multiple opponents. Cards like the new Varys, Whisper Campaign, and The Smalljon will bring new threats and deadly surprises into your already-tense multiplayer games.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Game: A Game of Thrones – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: Think: Namen & Gesichter
Description:
Another game of the Ravenburger Think Series. You could train your ability to remember names and hobbies of people you meet at a"party".
Everyone gets a number of people with their faces,names and hobbies. Then you roll and move around all the person from all players. When you hit a person for the first time you read aloud the name and the hobby of the person. being the second on a person´s portrait urges you to tell the name and the hobby.
Game when the 6th champaign bottle (on the die) was rolled

Name: Horus Line
Description:
The players must "pray" the mighty Horus, drawing from a bag wooden tokens in two different colours. The player in turn declares how many "pray token" will be able to draw from the bag, avoiding the negative colour. The player on the lefts has two options: he can overdeclare or he can "challenge". If he overdeclares, the player on his left can "challenge" or overdeclare and so on until one of the player challenges the last declaration. Now it's time to "pray", that is drawing one at a time, the tokens from the bag. A player succeeds if he's able to draw exactly the number of tokens declared without taking the wrong colour. If he fails the wrong token goes to the challenging player, while all the "pray tokens" go back into the bag.

The game was published in KidultGame's Game in a bag" line.

Name: Myrmex
Description:
An ant colony is a place of feverish activity, where workers endlessly toil for the greater good of the superorganism. You are a worker ant, constantly moving detritus and foodstuffs from chamber to chamber. The problem is that other workers are bringing in more goods faster than you can sort out the old stuff! At the end of the day, the best that you can hope for is a chance to do it all over again tomorrow.

Myrmex is an olde style solitaire game for the Decktet. Two Decktets are required to play. The object of the game is to organize all of the cards into 6 piles that share a single suit and are in descending rank order from Crown to Ace.

Myrmex is an engaging and utterly addictive Spider solitaire experience. Don’t play this game if you have something important to do today.

Name: Familiengeflüster
Description:
Familiengeflüster, which is aimed at families with small children, is about the wishes of the different family members. The game starts with family members writing down their wishes by finishing a sentence on a randomly selected card, such as "You will ... together with me." Then, they select a family member who should fulfull their wish.

In the next round, they try to communicate their wish by drawing it on the back of another player. If they can communicate their wish correctly, they gain a happiness card; otherwise, they gain an out-of-luck card.

Finally, all players vote on which wish is the best, to determine a "family wish" that should be carried out before the next game of Familiengeflüster.

Name: Behütunsburg
Description:
In 13th century Bayern, family ties were strong, but for some, the lust for power was stronger.  Rivalry among and within noble families would often lead to Machiavellian politics, outright theft and sometimes kidnapping. The Behütuns family was no different, as different branches of the family squabbled over money & subjects.

Gameplay:
Behütunsburg is a two-player card game usually played in 4 rounds. (Two copies of the game can be used to play with 3-4 players.)
Players will assemble a "court" of Barons & Knights with their Ladies, then a King and Queen, and finally adding a castle.  Each of these elements are worth a certain number of victory points. Knights can be sent on quests to find treasure and more vassals for the King, (i.e. drawing more cards).  Opposing players can attempt to disrupt plans by sending rogues to steal from the treasury or kidnap ladies, knights, barons or baronesses.

The round ends when a player with a complete court and castle discards their last card.  Scores are totaled based on the victory points of the cards in play.
The goal is to have the most total victory points at the end of four rounds of play.

Name: Twister Hoopla
Description:
Publisher's description:

It's a TWISTER game with a twist! Instead of the game mat, you get 16 colorful rings and five different ways to play! Game 1 challenges you to use your bodies to hold the rings in place and the last team standing wins. Game 2 is a ring toss with your hands and feet to catch! Game 3 is a race to make it to the finish line with colored rings in hand. Game 4 is a fun version of the traditional TWISTER game: scatter the rings and then call out the moves; but don't fall or you're out! Game 5 gets you all tangled up with other players as you reach for rings, hang on to your TWISTER and try to stay on your feet. Inside or out, this game makes sure you're ready to throw a TWISTER party just about anywhere!

Name: Cra$h
Description:
Cra$h is a simple dice game that utilizes probabilities, luck, and a lot of book keeping to simulate the vagaries of the stock market. The game is comprised of six rounds were each player takes a turn to try and beat the odds or try not to lose too much money.

Cra$h is a simple game and was envisioned to help parents encourage basic mathematics skill and to open children up to the idea of the stock market.

Cra$h uses 6 ten sided dice as the amount of money you wager on the stock market. you may choose to roll up to all six dice. This is then compared to the market mood die (the 7th d10) anything below this number loses cash(k), anything that beats the market gains cash(k), anything that matches gains 10k.When a Player rolls triples it causes a crash and all players need to roll to see how much they lost. With each player starting with only 50K this game is fast!

The game continues until there is only one player left or whoever has the most money at the end of six rounds.

Leiker Games
Give us a "Leik" on Facebook!

Name: Starship! The Game of Space Exploration
Description:
-Summary-
In Starship! you play as the captain of an enterprising ship and her crew searching for valuable cargo amongst the stars. Each turn you will be upgrading your ship, stowing away cargo, exploring new star Sectors and fighting to keep shield, weapons, and engine upgrades out of the hands of your opponents!

-Overview-
The game of Starship! is played in a series of turns where players reveal Star Sectors in order to conquer them and claim their resources. Other players may hinder your conquest by playing cards onto the revealed Star Sector card. If you you claim the cards in the Star Sector pile and can use those cards for Ship System upgrades, hindering your opponents or stowing one as cargo.

Leiker Games
Give us a "Leik" on Facebook!

Name: The American Civil War: A Rank & File Supplement
Description:
From their website:

A Supplement to Crusader Publishings Rank and File Rulebook.

The American Civil War supplement for Rank & File includes a historical background to the war as well as game aids that can be used with any rules system. There are optional and period specific rules as well as detailed weapon statistics, command ratings and army organisation.

Almost 1000 leader ratings for both sides of the conflict and army lists that are broken down by theatre and year allow players to design their own scenarios, create balanced forces for pick up games or calculate troop quality and strength for historical battles.

This supplement adds a further level of detail to the command and control aspect of Rank & File with a comprehensive order system that takes account of leader ratings, orders issued, distances and staff quality. Optional army morale rules allow large or small games to be played to a definite conclusion within an evening. This allows players to game larger conflicts with all of the problems and uncertainty of command that was a factor in so many ACW battles.

While much of the material included is of use with any rules system a copy of the Rank & File rules are required to gain the most from this supplement.

48page full colour perfect bound A4

Name: March Attack: Napoleonic Wargame Rules
Description:
From their website:

Napoleonic Wargames Rules.

March Attack are presented as an 80 page A4, full colour, perfect bound book. The rules are designed to allow players to fight large battles with battalion sized units in a reasonable amount of time.

Command and control, orders and morale for large formations are combined with easy to learn tactical game mechanics so that battles of a Corps or more a side 
can easily be fought by a few players during an evening. Each unit on the table represents a battalion of infantry, regiment of cavalry or battery of artillery.

A ground scale of 1" to 60 yards, one turn representing 20 minutes and fast paced strategic movement rules mean that battles play out at a realistic rate. Combat is dealt with in a manner that allows large numbers of units to be fielded and the interaction between strategic movement and tactical combat allows for a fast paced game that keeps a good level of detail.

Seven different training and morale levels combined with the historical strength of a unit introduces the concept of ‘Combat Value’. This ties together all of the tactical rules and ensures that troop quality, more than just luck or buckets of dice, plays an important part in every battle.

Name: Vad ritar Picasso?
Description:
How quickly can your teammates guess what you draw?
Stress, Laughter & nerve.
 In 45 seconds you have to draw so the team can guess right. The words to be guessed and drawn is pulled out of a bag, and for every correct word you get to add the tiles on the board. The first team to 20 correct answers wins. But beware of the "art thief", he steals the tiles from your team if the other teampulls him from the bag.

Name: Teenage Mutant  Hero Turtles Card Game
Description:
Card game for 2-5 players from ages 7 and up.

The purpose of the game is to be the first to collect all 4 turtles. every turn the players take a card from the face-down stack and put one from their hand on the face-up stack. Shredder card get their own stack. There are 3 special types of cards which let you skip a turn, take two shredder cards or change the turn-order.
Families: Comic Books: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles

Name: Hexomino
Description:
Hexomino is a logical game played on hex game board. The players place alternately six-colour plastic tiles on the board, so it matches at least two tiles on the board. Who can't place any tile onto the board, must draw three tiles. The player who first run out of tiles, is the winner.
There is a more complex variant of the game, in that every player place tiles on his/her own board, considering certain rules of simmetry of the tile's formations.

Name: Sargon's Kingdom
Description:
Check out an older tile based strategy PnP game by Leiker Games, it's FREE!!

-Overview-
Play as a great King in ancient Mesopotamia, take control of your city state, and balance the expansion of your towns and territory held, versus the conquest of your enemy. 
Two Game modes, Quick Battle and Grand Campaign, allows for different strategies and game length.

You can win via conquest of your opponents city state or economic victory, by building a set number of towns.

Sargon's Kingdom channels a little Carcassone (tile flipping and placement) and Settlers of Catan (Towns and resource generation) in this light beer and pretzels strategy game.

In SK Quick Battle, you start by laying a random 6x4 spread of tiles, Ore, Barley, Mountains, and Mountain Passes. The Grand battle sees you choosing were each drawn tile goes in an 8x6 spread.Each tile has a representative number that when rolled with a town built upon it, generates a resource. These resources can be used to build armies or towns.

Combat is undertaken by your armies that can stack up to a total of 3 armies per tile. Armies have different properties and abilities based on their stack size, Smaller armies can raze towns and move quickly, bigger armies can control occupied towns but move slowly. 
Combat is resolved using standard D6's. Each Army receives 1D6 when attacking or defending and receives a success on a 5+. results are compared and if the attacker has a larger number of successes they destroy one of the defenders armies.

Towns, Mountains, and Mountain passes can generate defensive bonuses for your armies and Towns built upon Mountain Passes act as fortresses. creating an interesting tactical imperative for the placement and disposition of your towns.

-Items you'll need-
1 Yellow City State- Triangle Stand
1 Green City State- Triangle Stand
10 Yellow Towns- Houses
10 Green Towns- Houses
10 Yellow Armies- Stackable Pawns
10 Green Armies- Stackable Pawns
6 6 sided dice (6D6)
(or some other equivalent, coins were used in early iterations)

-Items included in the PDF's-
24 Barley Resource Cards
24 Ore Resource Cards
48 Tiles

Available on DrivethruRPG.com and BGG.

CopyRight DigiPen IoT

Created by Keith Leiker
Leiker Games
Give us a "Leik" on Facebook!

Name: Flipp!
Description:
Flipp! is a game where you came up with words that are difficult for the opposing team to explain.

Players are divided in two teams. Then dice are rolled to determine which letters teams have to use in their words. Then hourglasses are turned and teams formulate words based on the letters given earlier. The opposing teams has exactly the same amount of time to figure out the words that your team spent formulating them.

A team gets a point for every word they guess. For every word that is not guessed the opposing team gets two points. Both teams have a pawn that is moved forwards on a game board when they score points. The first team to make it to the finish is the winner.

The Nordic version has seven dice of which four are language dependant.

This game is actually an early version of Tic Talk and Wordy Word; in later versions the dice have become d12's, otherwise it's pretty much the same game.

Name: Monopoly: BBK Worldwide Clinical Research & Development Edition
Description:
Themed Monopoly giveaway at the 2007 Drug Information Association (DIA) conference in Atlanta.

From Game Box:

Now, the world's foremost patient recruitment products, services, and technology company brings you a special edition of America's favorite board game!

With the MONOPOLY BBK Worldwide Clinical Research & Development Edition, now you can experience all the challenges and excitement of studying investigational treatments, enrolling clinical trials, and gaining the leading edge in the global clinical development marketplace.  Build a study site on Investigator Avenue!  Buy all four Study Phases!  But watch out for your competitor's research centers on Patient Place and Blockbuster!  It's lots of fun for the family, perfect for that office retreat, even gives new definition to your board meetings!

So, for all you to do help improve medicine and healthcare throughout the world, Advance to GO, Collect $200, and enjoy a hard-earned, exciting game of MONOPOLY with our compliments - from the innovative and fun-loving people at BBK Worldwide.

Name: Redakai: Metacharged
Description:
The MetaCharged expansion will add a whole new element to Redakai game play by making monsters more powerful and aggressive.

The new release includes 75 new monsters and attacks for the world’s only Blast 3-D TCG.  The expansion adds considerably to gameplay with new "Metacharge" attacks that enables players to get the most out their monsters by making them more powerful and aggressive than ever.
 Metacharged Power Packs will contain 11 cards (with one rare or super rare), while Metacharged Gold Packs include 6 cards (with one rare or super rare and one hobby-exclusive Gold Pack rare).

Name: Super Mario Balance Block
Description:
User Summary

Super Mario Balance Block is similar to the game of Jenga, but with a theme based on the Super Mario series of videogames. Players push out bricks from a tower and place them back on top. The player who makes the tower collapse is the loser! The art style features blocks from the Mario games, including the iconic question mark blocks. It also includes a Mario stick that is used to push the blocks and Super Mushrooms that add a unique twist.
Families: Video Game Theme: Super Mario Bros.

Name: Make Frank's Monsters
Description:
Frank Einstein is known for his monsters... and his factory makes the best monsters bar none.

Make Frank's Monsters is four different card games that can be played with the same deck of cards. Although each of the four games are a little different in theme and play; basically you are trying to build  monsters by getting the four different cards needed (the Lightning Bolt /Helmet, the Head, the Arms/Torso and the Legs) to complete a monster and score points. But, when things don't quite work out you can lose points. Starting with Make Frank's Monsters 1, each of the four games are a little more complex and strategic then the previous game.

The  deck consists of 64 cards: the 4 types of cards,  in 4 different colors (Red, Blue, Yellow and Gray) with 4 of each card in the deck. In the first two games the colors are not used, but in the last two they are. There are also two kinds of  tokens (the +3 tokens and the -1 tokens) which are used for scoring.

Name: Reds
Description:
Reds is a trick-taking game for 2-6 players played with a standard deck which has the suit of hearts removed. Reds uses some interesting mechanics, including an anti-trump suit which will almost always lose a trick, bidding which encourages risk-taking and rewards skill, and variable exchange of cards which leads the game through several different stages of luck and strategy.

Called "Reds" due to diamonds being trump, this is an interesting use of a three-suited deck.

Each round is 5 tricks, and each game is 9 rounds.  The deal is a straight rotation, moving clockwise every round.  Each round, players bid before a pre-determined amount of cards in their hand are passed to another player.  This allows for interesting strategy and even an element of bluffing.  As the game wraps up, fewer and fewer cards are passed, lending the game a transition from heavily luck-based to heavily skill-based.

Playable with a standard deck (hearts removed), a pad, and a pencil.

Name: Breadcrumbs
Description:
Breadcrumbs is an abstract strategy game for two to five players with a modular board and partial shared-point mechanics.

In Breadcrumbs, players take turns moving to claim sections of the board, which translate into points. If a player claims a tile that matches their color, they claim double points. But, players must be careful of their movements, as revisiting a tile that you've already moved to results in you losing your claim! And beware, other players can stake a claim into your tiles to reduce your points and claim some of their own!

Name: Memoir '44: The Invasion of Crete
Description:
A six scenario booklet similar to The Vercors Campaign. The scenarios were used in the World Boardgame Championship 2011 and will be published in Q4/2011.

Description from Days of Wonder forums:
This year's theme will be a unique moment in military history: Operation Mercury, the German invasion Crete in May, 1941 -- the first large airborne invasion in history, where over 15,000 German paratroops and glider troops landed at several strategic points on the island. In addition, it was the first time the British made major use of intelligence gathered from the deciphered Enigma code -- they knew when the invasion was coming. The battle consisted of ten days of brutal, back-and-forth fighting.

Name: The Smurfs Tag-athon!
Description: A collectible miniatures game sold in single figure blind packaging. A game can be played with as few as 4 figures to as many as both player's agree. (Three or four figures per player is best.) To start the game, each player places a small object on their side of the table and nominates it as their base. Next all of the Smurf figures are placed in contact with their designated base. The object of the game is to be the first to tag your opponent's base. Each turn, a player may move his entire team of Smurfs. To do so, he may move the length of one standard playing card (such as the the enclosed rule card) an any direction indicated by the arrows on the smurf figure's base. If at anytime you can move one of your Smurfs into base contact with an opponent's Smurf, you may immediately move EVERY Smurf on the opponent's team (including the one you tagged) the distance of two short sides of the card, again in any direction indicated on the Smurfs base. The first one to tag the opposing base, wins!

Name: Stern Wissensquiz: Die neunziger Jahre
Description:
Quiz game for 2-4 players or teams. 
Questions are all about the nineties.
Be the first/best after 20 rounds.

All players including the player who asked the question put a token (with the answer they think is the correct one ==> multiple choice) in the middle - the less correct answers the more you can move forward - if you were right. 
Special (red) questions for additional moves:
Die is used to determine the year - make a guess if the requested event happened earlier, later or during that year.

Content: 
200 cards - with 4 questions per card
4 large & 4 small meeples (scoring positions month & year)
10-sided die
1 board
24 answer cards 
1 rule sheet & solutions
No extensions were published - but different editions regarding other decades.

Name: Stern Wissensquiz: Die achtziger Jahre
Description:
Quiz game for 2-4 players or teams. 
Questions are all about the eighties.
Be the first/best after 20 rounds.

All players including the player who asked the question put a token (with the answer they think is the correct one ==> multiple choice) in the middle - the less correct answers the more you can move forward - if you were right. 
Special (red) questions for additional moves:
Die is used to determine the year - make a guess if the requested event happened earlier, later or during that year.

Content: 
200 cards - with 4 questions per card
4 large & 4 small meeples (scoring positions month & year)
10-sided die
1 board
24 answer cards 
1 rule sheet & solutions
No extensions were published - but different editions regarding other decades.

Name: Stern Wissensquiz: Die siebziger Jahre
Description:
Quiz game for 2-4 players or teams. 
Questions are all about the seventies.
Be the first/best after 20 rounds.

All players including the player who asked the question put a token (with the answer they think is the correct one ==> multiple choice) in the middle - the less correct answers the more you can move forward - if you were right. 
Special (red) questions for additional moves:
Die is used to determine the year - make a guess if the requested event happened earlier, later or during that year.

Content: 
200 cards - with 4 questions per card
4 large & 4 small meeples (scoring positions month & year)
10-sided die
1 board
24 answer cards 
1 rule sheet & solutions
No extensions were published - but different editions regarding other decades.

Name: Characters from Charles Dickens
Description:
52 cards, forming 13 sets of four, that is, four characters from the same book.
You will need a number of coins or buttons before play begins because, as was often the case in Victorian games, players must place a stake into the 'Pool', which will go to the eventual winner.
Play involves a player leading a character card, say, from Oliver Twist. The next player must follow suit if he has an Oliver Twist character in his hand. The next does likewise and if a trick is completed, the player completing takes the cards and they will form one trick. If a player wins 3 tricks before the cards are exhausted, he wins the game.
The date is a guess but it must be in the late 1850's because three books are not mentioned, including Great Expectations, which were not published until after that time.

Name: Achtung Ampel!
Description: Children's game with a message "Take care on the roads". This concentrates on advising about traffic lights. On the box, a cute bear and a blue dog are helping two children to cross the road safely.

Name: Air Race
Description:
Simple roll and move game, given away free with a birthday card. Roll the die and move along the track, obeying good and bad instructions that you land on.
Probably 1950's I think

Name: The Centenary Amusu Electrical Game
Description:
From the box "Educational and Instructive".
Trivia game relating to Australia.
Point your 'plug' at a question it is your turn to answer. Then place your plug into the answer mode and a light will indicate the correct answer. The player who gets the most correct answers, wind. Probably very hi-tech for 1933.

Two versions exist. The Centenary of Victoria and the earlier general version of the game

The game's name may reference the AMUSU cinemas which operated in Australia (Sydney, Perth and Maroubra, NSW) and in the United States (California, Texas, etc) at the time.

Name: Tic Tac Turn
Description:
You’d think getting 4 in a row was easy!  Not with Tic Tac Turn, the classic game with a new spin.  Make your move on your choice of 4 levels OR give a level a turn.  Watch out, the turn you make may just line up someone else’s pieces.  Easy to learn and fun for the whole family!

Similar to:

    Qubic - Played on 4x4x4 cube (4x4 grid with 4 layers) but without turning layers
    Score Four - 4x4 grid of pegs that are filled from the bottom up
    Dimensions(1970), Hi!Noon: Das Duell(2009), and X: Die 4. Dimension - the 4 individual horizontal board layers (4x4 each) of the 4x4x4 grid can turn
    3D5 - which is played on a 5x5x5 cube (5x5 grid with 5 layers) but without turning layers

Name: Nightfall: Ahmad Hassan Promo
Description:
Publisher blurb to be added here

Ahmad Hassan introduces a new vampire and a new color combination to Nightfall. With Ahmad's In Play text, your opponents will be forced to risk taking damage themselves just to attack you!

The pack comes pre-wrapped with:

     1 Ahmad Hassan draft card
     7 Ahmad Hassan cards


The card divider for this card comes with the Nightfall: Martial Law box.

Name: Nightfall: Desperate Measures Promo
Description:
Publisher blurb to be added here

Desperate Measures introduces a new action and a new color combination to Nightfall. Its Feed effect can help you hunt down that c-c-combo card you're searching for, but be wary of the cost!

The pack comes pre-wrapped with:

     1 Desperate Measures draft card
     7 Desperate Measures cards


The card divider for this card comes with the Nightfall: Martial Law box.

Name: Nightfall: Pale Fury Promo
Description:
Publisher blurb to be added here

"Pale Fury" introduces a huge new lycanthrope to Nightfall. Be careful however, as a minion as powerful as "Pale Fury" is difficult to control, often causing destruction among his own ranks!

The pack comes pre-wrapped with:

     1 Pale Fury draft card
     7 Pale Fury cards


The card divider for this card comes with the Nightfall: Martial Law box.

Name: San Guo Sha: Mountain
Description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

    
    
         The information that BGG has on this item indicates that San Guo Sha is an unauthorized reproduction of BANG! with just a few differences, published in China and distributed in several coutries of the world.

    


This is the fourth character expansion of San Guo Sha, or the Killers of the Three Kingdoms. This expansion introduces 10 new characters including 8 ordinary characters and 2 Demi-God characters randomly inserted into some packets.

The 10 characters are:

Shu Kingdom: Liu Chan, Jiang Wei;
Wei Kingdom: Zhang He, Deng Ai;
Wu Kingdom: Sun Ce, Zhang Zhao&Zhang Hong[1]; 
Qun: Zuo Ci, Cai Wenji.  
Two Demi-God: God Si Mayi, God Zhao Yun.

[1] Zhang Zhao&Zhang Hong are two characters on the same card, like Yan Liang&Wen Zhou in the Fire Expansionï¼‰
Families: Theme: Romance of the Three Kingdoms

Name: The Bombardier
Description:
Australian action game.

Aim your 'bombs' and catapult them into the box. The insert features various holes, just big enough to 'receive' one of your bombs. If your bomb ends in a hole, you score points.

"You'll have explosions of laughter" according to the box.

Name: The Grand Naval Game of Tactics
Description:
Australian game of World War II vintage or slightly earlier.
Box features a group of adults playing game. The box contains a board pierced with holes, around 400 wooden coloured matchstick-type pieces and the rules. Each player controls his own fleet at the same time trying to locate the enemy forces.
I think this must be a Battleships-type game but the pieces, that you thrust through the board to hopefully score a hit, are different colours and this must have some effect on game-play. The manufacturer describe it a "Thrill for Adults". But, covering all bases, it is also suggested for children. Nice to see wooden components.

Name: Vector Chess
Description:
VECTOR CHESS is a war game that was developed from a combination of the term “vector”, which is a quantity used to represent magnitude and direction, and “chess”, one of the world’s oldest war games. Each piece in this game has a rank that determines the distance it may move, and a directional characteristic which indicates the direction that it may be moved. In this way, each piece represents a vector, having characteristics of both magnitude and direction.

PLAYING SURFACE: Vector Chess is played on a square playing area divided into either 49 or 64 smaller squares of equal size. The squares may be alternately light and dark colored, but it is not necessary. A game played on the board having 49 squares will usually make for a shorter game when compared to a game on the 64 square board.

THE PIECES: Depending upon the type of board used, enough pieces must be used to fill the first two rows of squares on each side of the board, with each piece set facing the opposite side of the board. Only two types of pieces are used in this game: the MAJOR pieces, and the MINOR pieces. The major pieces, which are line up along the first row of the board, have the highest rank and may be moved from one to four spaces along a straight line in the direction that they are pointing. The minor pieces are lined up on the second row of the board, and are identical to the major pieces except that they are shorter and may be moved only one or two spaces in the direction that they are pointing. Each piece in this game maneuvers like a soldier on a battlefield – it may turn and move to a new position, provided no other piece blocks its path, and it may attack any enemy piece that is directly in its path and within range. The range of movement is the number of spaces that the piece move can move as was previously described.

OBJECT OF THE GAME: The object of the game is to “check mate” the opposing player by maneuvering pieces into his first row squares until the defending pieces in that row are outnumbered. If the first row squares are empty, only one attacking pieces is required to put the opposing player “in check”. The defending player must break the check during his next turn as described below, or he will be considered “check mated”.

COMPONENTS: This game includes 32 round wooden playing pieces in 2 colors that are similar looking to a rook in chess but have a directional arrow in the top. For each player there are 8 'tall' pieces and 8 'short' pieces that otherwise look identical. The board included has a 7x7 grid on a rolled up vinyl board (although the game can also be played on an 8x8 grid - presumably a standard chess board would be suitable)

Name: Race-Play
Description:
Australian action game. 
You get eight plastic horses, a good size, to which is attached a length of string (around 1 metre). The strings are unwound to their full length and will stretch from the control box to the start line . At the start everyone frantically rewinds their string. The first horse to reach the control box, wins.
The horses are named after celebrated  Australian thoroughbreds (including Phar Lap).
There is no clear winner although I think it will be the richest player after a number of pre-set races. There is no recommendation who should be the Bookie. A non-player would be favourite for that task.

Name: 2 de Mayo: Assault on Palace Grimaldi
Description:
What if the Spaniards had assaulted Palace Grimaldi and taken Murat prisoner? What if the King's Dragoons had charged? Or what if the French had not used their artillery? Would their principles of Liberty, Equality and Fraternity have been better regarded?

In 2 de Mayo: Assault on Palace Grimaldi, players can explore these and other possibilities, as well as six new game modes (including a double draft and customized modes) of the original game 2 de Mayo.

The expansion consists of a rulebook and 44 cards: 22 new cards and the 22 original cards adapted to play the expansion.

Name: Pingu Acts Up
Description:
A Pingu-themed gamed combining Roll & Move with Charades.
Players play as Pingu, Pinga, Bajoo or Robby the Seal & race to reach the start of the 'I See Slide'.
Along the way, there are 'Act Up' spaces where a player may draw a card & then perform the charade listed. these range from 'Brushing your teeth' & 'Flying a toy plane' to 'Pingu Boogaloo'. If the other players guess your charade, you keep the card & get the points listed on it.
Once a player has reached the start of the Slide, all players move there. Once someone crosses the finish line, the game is over.
The winner is the one who has scored the most points from their charades.

Name: Im Kreuzverhör
Description:
As a criminalist you try to solve a murder by interrogating a witness. You can ask the witness about the characteristics and the motives of the culprit as well as about the found evidence.

A game consists of several rounds. In each round one of the players is the witness and randomly selects one of the cards indicating the guilty person. The criminalist whose turn it is  shows the witness one of the characteristics, motives or evidence cards. The witness then answers (mostly truthfully, though there are exceptions, when he is allowed to lie or refuse the answer). Based on these answers the other players try to find the culprit. The aim is to be the first person to guess correctly. Then the next player becomes the new witness.

The game ends after all players have been the witness the same number of times.

Name: Gypsy Queen Fortune Telling Cards and The Game of Stars
Description:
36 cards. Half a fortune telling accessory and half a game. The important part of the rules, the Game of Stars, is a card game in the spirit of Black Maria in Britain or Hearts in America.
Two to four persons can play. The cards rank in the order indicated by the number in the corner, 1 being low. The cards are dealt one at a time until each player has eight cards. The object of the game is to avoid taking tricks which contain cards in the unlucky suit of Stars. There are four suits, Squares, Circles, Diamonds and Stars. The highest numbered card of suit played wins the trick. Players must follow suit if they can. After each hand every player counts the number of unlucky cards (Stars) he has had to take. Every Star card counts one against him and the winner of each hand wins one point for each Star card in his opponents' tricks. First player to get 25 points wins the game. 
The unlucky Stars are:
1. Pride
2. Danger
3. Malice
4. Gossip
5. Calamity
6. Envy and Jealousy
7. Sickness
8. Disappointment
9. Tears and Sorrow

Name: Bundesliga
Description: In this game 2 players play on a soccerfield with 2 teams of each 11 players. The game board has points and lines on wich the player or the ball "move". The same rules as in the "real" socder game apply. The players move the team members and the ball around as if they were running or the ball has been shot. To figure out how far the player and the ball can "go" one uses a "fight roulette" (loosly translated). It is a small can with two balls in it. The yellow ball indicates how far the ball will move and the blue how far the player can move one or more of his teamplayers. The playing time is 2 x 15 minutes.

Name: Zwiffel
Description:
Zwiffel includes rules for two games: Flaggenspiel and Zahlenspiel. It was published about 1992-1994 as a Volksbank promotional giveaway.

In Zahlenspiel players try to build ascending rows of 6 cards.
The 32 cads are numbered from 1 to 32. The deck is shuffled and than each player is dealt 6 cards face down. Each player places his cards in front of him in a row with the face down. The rest of the cards go in the center to draw from. The starting player reveals the first card of the stack and chooses a card in front of him that he replaces with the drawn card face up. He than reveals the replaced card and gives it to his left neighbor. That player again chooses one of his cards to be replaced by the given card. 
The first player to form a row of six ascending numbers wins the game.

Flaggenspiel is a regular game of Memory.

Name: Mouse blaster
Description:
On this (quite literally) cat and mouse game, two rounds are played, with each player taking the role of the cat or the mouse in each of them. The one controlling the mouse must move it with a magnetic stick around the course, go to one end where there's a cheese and go back to his shelter, while avoiding the tomatos thrown by the player controlling the cat, who tries to knock down the mouse as much times as he can before it escapes.

After both players have played controlling the cat, the one who knocked off the mouse more times wins the game.

Name: Kolonix
Description:
KOLONIX a board game in which colonize the-deal-free squares on the board by placing them in our leading disc (figure).
Figure consists of two basic discs.
Movement of the disc leading to 2-1 (two to one in the front side) is the same as chess horse. After each made â€‹â€‹free movement in our field is marked with color and not taking no further part in the game giving us a point-to-colonization.
The game objective is to take as many free fields by colonization, and acquisition or breaking the puck leading opponent, this is possible when the opponent can within our movement.
You can win with the difference or completely occupied the field to "0" if you take over the puck leading opponent.


KOLONIX to gra planszowa w której kolonizujemy-zajmujemy wolne pola na planszy poprzez umieszczenie na nich naszego krÄ…Å¼ka prowadzÄ…cego (figury). 
Figura skÅ‚ada siÄ™ z dwóch krÄ…Å¼ków podstawowych.
Ruch krÄ…Å¼ka prowadzÄ…cego to 2-1 (dwa do przodu jedno w bok) jest  identyczny jak konika szachowego. Po kaÅ¼dym wykonanym ruchu wolne pole zostaje oznaczone naszym kolorem i nie bierze juÅ¼ dalszego udziaÅ‚u w grze dajÄ…c nam 1 punkt-kolonizacji. 
Celem gry jest zajÄ™cie jak najwiÄ™kszej liczby wolnych pól przez kolonizacjÄ™ oraz przejÄ™cie czyli zbicie krÄ…Å¼ka prowadzÄ…cego przeciwnika, jest to moÅ¼liwe gdy przeciwnik stanie  w zasiÄ™gu naszego ruchu.
WygraÄ‡ moÅ¼na dziÄ™ki róÅ¼nicy zajÄ™tych pól lub zupeÅ‚nie do „0” jeÅ›li przejmiemy krÄ…Å¼ek prowadzÄ…cy przeciwnika.

Name: Archipel
Description:
You are tourists racing to be the first one to visit all seven of the islands that comprise the Îles-de-la-Madeleine.

To do so you collect cards in hand that match one of the three possible current destinations. When you have the correct number of cards in hand to visit one of the available islands, you collect a token representing your visit there. In the end game, you also have the option of stealing tokens from other players.

The first player to have one of each token wins.

Name: Criterium. El gran juego del ciclismo
Description:
This game covers almost every aspect of a cycling race. It features rules for ascension, sprint, time trial (even a different rule for mountain time trial), and provides mechanism to run a single race.

The board is customisable with the provided little arrows.  It is just a plain 100-field board.Before the race you must decide how long will it be (recommended: 150 to 250 squares long for a one-day race, that is one and a half to two and a half laps) and where you place the different mountains and sprints.

What is puzzling is that you have to remember (and possibly write down) in which lap are placed the mountains. In effect, it is recommended to have three climbs during the race, and each climb takes place in a different lap. The same applies to special sprints. So you end up with a board with too many arrow pointing at mountains and sprints that might or might not be there.
We have six national teams  of 5 riders each, and every rider has different abilities which affect the probability of having a good throw on a given type of road. As you can see in the team cards, riders have values for flat road (LL = "llano"), mountain (M), sprint (S), time trial (CR = "contra reloj") and mountain time trial (CRM).

On an even closer look, you will guess that good values is the lower one (9) for flat roads (LL) and the higher for mountains sprints and time trials. This is because in flat road riders throw two dice and they have an extra throw if they match their number on the team card (and of course, it is more probable to throw 9 than 12 with two dice, though when you get an extra throw after a double sic, you really advance a lot)

The mountain rule is quite strange. You still throw two dice, but you only advance the value of the blue one. The red dice is just added to the blue to see if you match the number on the card and you have an extra throw.

Similar rules apply to sprint and time trial. Just roll and move. No decisions to be taken. The only strategic issue in the game is the demarrage card. One is given to each player, to be used only once during the race, and giving you an extra throw for one rider. 
The game is intended to run a full season, so we have special maillots (yellow, green and rainbow jerseis) medals and a trophy, and rules to decide how many points is worth a given race.

Name: Husky: Invasion of Sicily
Description:
From the publisher:

The seas are still running high from last night's storm.  The troops have started loading into the landing crafts, anxious to get to land or anywhere away from the rolling Mediterranean.  The High Command has assured you that with the force under your command it will be impossible for the Axis forces to stop you from taking control of Sicily.

You have been given command of the defense of Sicily.  Report have been coming in every 20 to 30 minutes of another Allied landing.  The High Command has promised you that in the event of an Allied landing you will be given sufficient reinforcements to destroy them on the beaches.

Game components include one rule booklet, one 19" x 25" map board, four counter sheets, playing charts, one six-sided die, and two plastic bags.

Name: En Avant!: Rules for the Napoleonic Wargame
Description: A 40-page rule booklet telling how to recreate Napoleonic battles with a 1-20 historical ratio (1" = 20 yards).  Each move simulates 2.5 minutes.  Highlights include: simultaneous movement, morale, accurate table of organizational equipment, and suggested army compositions.  Optional rules tell how to switch over to the Crimean War and the War of 1812.

Name: The Old West Gunfight Rules 1816-1900
Description:
Publisher Blurb

Born a century too late?  Well, the Old West Gunfight Rules capture all the excitement and adventure of the Old West.  Jail breaks, cattle drives through hostile Indian country, Mexican revolutions, range wars, knife fights, and shoot-outs are only a few of the cultural activities recreated by these rules.  Requires percentile dice.

User Summary

Later printings (such as the one labeled "New 3rd Edition" on the cover) included a sample sprue of Atlantic plastic 25mm figures inserted into the ziplock.

Name: Advanced Fighter Combat
Description:
A supplement to the Basic Fighter Combat rules, Advanced Fighter Combat gives gamers nine more fighters and fifteen additional performance logs as well as more bombers, greater realism, math elimination tables and a campaign game system.  The equipment in this set can be used with the basic game by players who prefer simple games, or the basic game equipment can be used with these rules for more realism and challenge.  Ideal for use with 1/133 and 1/72 scale models.

Ownership of the Basic Fighter Combat Rules is required to play the game.

Name: Wargods of Hyberborea
Description:
From the playtest manual:

'There is a Greek legend that tells of a frozen land at the top of the world, a place many days sail beyond the most northerly human settlement. Here the cold sea is studded with floating mountains of ice, turning the waters into a frothing tempest that can crush the hulls of the strongest ships and freeze the bodies of the unfortunate sailors who dared to sail there. The land beyond the frozen sea is Ultima Thule.'

Wargods of Hyberborea is a tabletop miniatures game using metal miniatures that is closely related to Wargods of Aegyptus and Wargods of Olympus. Unlike many other tabletop miniatures wargames, the Wargods system uses hidden activation counters in order to simulate fog of war.

In this reincarnation, players simulate massive battles in the land of Ultima Thule by taking control of a race of fierce creatures called the Wendigo, who are led to battle by formidable Ice Witches, masters of snow and wind. Although one off clashes occur frequently between warring factions, Wargods of Hyberborea offers dedicated warmongers an immersive game play experience through campaign play. In campaigns, players play through scenarios, progressing to differing scenarios and acquiring new special powers for their Wargod depending on who the victor is.

Name: Wargamer's Guide to the American Revolution
Description: Gaming rules, orders of battle and historical commentary on the period 1775 to 1783.  Includes complete guide on how to assemble needed miniatures.  52 pp.

Name: Tricorne
Description: Detailed set of wargame rules and background material on the Seven Years War for 20mm to 30mm miniatures.  Special section on unit formations of this period and how to duplicate them on the wargame table.  50 pages.

Name: Castle Panic: Feather Promo
Description:
This bookmark was given at Origins 2011 and GenCen 2011 and is intended for use in the game. Its text reads:

"Once per game you may play this bookmark in addition to any cards in your hand. Any monster with a Tar token on it is immediately slayed."

The obverse of the bookmark has endorsements of the base game, Castle Panic.

Name: Бородинское сражение 1812
Description:
Another game from Status Belli in series about key battles in Russian history. New wargame from Status Belli covers the key battle of Napoleon's Russian campaign. French player have to break through Russian lines and try to achieve decisive victory on Russians. Russian player have to defend his fortified positions and keep his army strong enough for further battles.

Game scale. 
1 hex is 1 km.
1 turn is 2 hours.
The counters represent division or brigade level unit.

Name: Target For Tonight
Description: Australian action game. Players hold their 'bomb' over the boards and drop the bomb, hoping it will end up in one of several holes. Rather like Bagatelle, you score points if it does go into a hole.

Name: Numenko
Description:
The Numenko board game resembles Scrabble in that players have wooden tiles and lay valid combinations of tiles in horizontal and vertical rows, sometimes reusing tiles on the board in their current plays.

What differs is that the tiles in Numenko feature digits (0-9), a Multichoice symbol (that stands for the player's choice of addition, subtraction, multiplication, division or "is equal to"), and a Freechoice symbol (that can be a digit or Multichoice).

Each player starts with eight tiles on his rack. On a turn, a player plays one or more tiles to the game board (possibly using tiles already in play) to create a valid equation, with the operators being resolved left to right or top to bottom, except for division which always takes place first.
